    Words of Wisdom #1

    Starting a new blog series at Set Physics to Stun! While most of my posts are based on my own experience, observations, or creations in science and scientific management, I wanted to bring in some opinions beyond my biases. So hereby I start “Words of Wisdom”, a blogging series where I shortly interview seasoned professionals in the world of science management. I will bring their inspiring words to burning questions tapping their expertise.

    For this first entry, I bring words from my own work colleague Shengtao Wang. Shengtao is a quantum information scientist with a career spanning Singapore, Michigan, and most recently Harvard University in Boston. He is one of QuEra Computing’s first employees and manages a 10+ team of theorists and computer scientits working in algorithms and applications.

    Here we go for Shengtao’s words of wisdom:

    SPTS: When it comes to time allocation, what would you say are the main challenges and peculiarities of managing a scientific team?

    SW: The key challenge is the capacity to align a team’s priorities and motivation. If you succeed at doing that, even if delays happen in a given project, you will know that the team’s strong motivation is targeted at the highest possible priority.

    SPTS: How do you view motivation? What are the key factors that keep a scientific team motivated?

    SW: To stay motivated, scientists really need room for creativity and critical thinking. Discovery is culturally important for scientists. Securing and respecting that space is essential for successful team managers and leaders.

    SPTS: What is the main “danger” or “tripping hazard” a scientific manager may face?

    SW: Lack of vision from a leader is a danger. But, when present, too strong a vision can lead to micromanagement, which is also dangerous. Failing at the former may affect prioritization. Failing at the latter will affect motivation. Both are important.

    SPTS: How do you distinguish the above in an academic vs private environments?

    SW: In my view, industry requires much more management because of more competing priorities. Several academic labs succeed with self-organization and adaptation of work direction. In industry, the existence of a company’s and a team’s vision means that keeping everyone aligned brings competing factors, thus requiring more structure.

    That is it! Thanks Shengtao for your Words of Wisdom! Set Physics to Stun hears you!
